absolute convergence criterion: |x^(t+1)-x^(t)| < epsilon
relative convergence criterion: |x^(t+1)-x^(t)|/|x^(t)| < epsilon
use updated endpoint a_{t+1} = a_t + (b_t-a_t)/2 is more numerically stable than a_{t+1} = (b_t-a_t)/2
stopping rule, based on some convergence criteria
bisection method
54598FF9-F62E-4D46-B3BE-6DD2E5FBEB23
so x*=x^(t)-g’(x^(t))/g’’(x^(t)) = x^(t)+h^(t)
where h^(t) is equal to minus first derivative of x^(t) divided by second derivative of x^(t)
x^(t+1) = x^(t) + h^(t)
approach approximates g’(x*) by the Taylor series expansion: 0=g’(x*) almost equals to g’(x^(t))+(x*-x^(t))g’’(x^(t)).
fast in univariate applications
whether converges depends on the shape of g and the starting value
1. g’’(x) != 0 on [a, b]
2. g’’’(x) does not change sign on [a, b]
3. g’(a)g’(b) < 0, and
EF54344C-D1DA-45FB-BB1F-7ADD66CBA19D
4. |g’(x)/g’’(a)| < b - a and |g’(b)/g’’(b)| < b - a

when g’ is twice continuously differentiable, is convex, and has a root, then Newton’s method converges to the root from any starting point. When starting from somewhere in an interval [a, b], another set of conditions one may check is as follows. If

a method has convergence of order beta if lim_{t->infinity}epsilon^(t)=0 and lim_{t->infinity}|epsilon^(t+1)}|/|epsilon^(t)|^beta = c for some non-empty constant c and beta > 0

Newton’s method is quadratic convergence, fast: precision of the solution will double with each iteration
5E4AB053-3D1C-405F-B68E-2E49FBEB4BE4

convergence order: the speed of a root-finding approach like Newton’s method is measured by its order of convergence
2.1.1 Newton’s Method
idea: replace -l’’(theta) in the Newton update with I(theta)
Fisher scoring works better in the beginning to make rapid improvements, while Newton’s method works better for refinement near the end
2.1.2 Fisher scoring
so the updating equation is now x^(t+1) = x^(t) - g’(x^(t))(x^(t) - x^(t-1))/(g’(x^(t)) - g’(x^(t-1))), for t >= 1
if hard to calculate, replace it with the discrete-difference approximation, [g’(x^(t))-g’(x^(t-1))]/(x^(t)-x^(t-1)), this is called the secant method
the updating increment for Newton’s method relies on the second derivative, g’’(x^(t))
has order close to 1.62, so slower than Newton’s method

the absolute and relative convergence criteria can be formed from the inequalities (like univariate cases)
D(u, v) is the distance between two p-dimensional vectors
seek the optimum of a real-valued function g of a p-dimensional vector x = (x_1, …, x_p)^T, x^(t) = (x_1^(t), …, x_p^(t))^T is the estimated optimum after t iterations.

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf130 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue-Italic;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural

gradient g’(x) is g’(x) = [dg(x)/dx_1, dg(x)/dx_2, …, dg(x)/dx_p]^T
“Hessian” g’’(x) is a p-by-p symmetric matrix filled with derivatives (2nd-order)
D77C8CF4-B1A4-47EF-91AD-7ECD2E88124B
so update x^(t+1) = x^(t) - g’’(x^(t))^(-1)g’(x^(t))

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf130 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 HelveticaNeue-Italic;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;} \pard\tx560\tx1120\tx1680\tx2240\tx2800\tx3360\tx3920\tx4480\tx5040\tx5600\tx6160\tx6720\pardirnatural

set the gradient equal to zero, so g’(x^(t)) = g’’(x^(t))(x* - x^(t)) = 0

so we can write any g(x*) = g(x^(t)) + (x* - x^(t))^Tg’(x^(t)) + 1/2*(x* - x^(t))^Tg’’(x^(t))(x* - x^(t))
